resources.string: Tension Pneumothorax Rt, complete Rt lung collapse and shift of mediastinum to left
Tension Pneumothorax Rt, Complete collapse Rt, left mediastinum shift.
Heart is enlarged pulmonary vasculature prominent, and interstitial markings are prominent consistent with congestive cardiac failure. \nNo consolidation. \nNo pleural collections.
PA and lateral chest x-rays demonstrate markedly enlarged cardiac silhouette. \nThere is a double contour to the right heart border and splaying of the carina. \nThe aorta is somewhat ectatic.
Multiple, large, well-circumscribed lesions are seen in the lung parenchyma bilaterally.
Pneumothorax on the right, with associated pulmonary collapse, without deviations from the mediastinal structures.
Chest X-ray showing the features of pneumothorax on the apical region of both lungs.

Hyperinflated lungs as indicated by flattened diaphragms. \nThe upper lobes are relatively radiolucent compared to the lower lobes, in particular the right upper lobe with less prominent bronchovascular markings.
There is a large volume of free subdiaphragmatic gas with air-fluid levels under rt hemidiaphragm.

In anatomy, the costophrenic angles are the places where the diaphragm (-phrenic) meets the ribs (costo-). Each costophrenic angle can normally be seen as on chest x-ray as a sharply-pointed, downward indentation (dark) between each hemi-diaphragm (white) and the adjacent chest wall (white)

Right atrial (RA) enlargement is less common, and harder to delineate on chest radiograph, than left atrial (LA) enlargement. Enlargement of the right atrium (RA) can result from a number of conditions, including: 
Raised right ventricular pressures, 
Valvular disease (tricuspid regurgitation, tricuspid stenosis, Ebstein anomaly), 
Atrial septal defect (ASD), 
Atrial fibrillation (AF), 
Dilated cardiomyopathy.
Radiograph showing the Shmoo sign for left ventricular enlargement. The shape of the Shmoo superimposed over the radiograph demonstrates the origin of this sign.
The carina is splayed and a double right heart border is seen. \nThe heart is enlarged and upper zone pulmonary vasculature is prominent particularly in the right upper zone.

If the patient is rotated then interpretation may become difficult. Firstly, it may be difficult to know if the trachea is deviated to one side by a disease process. It also becomes difficult to comment accurately on the heart size. \nChanges in lung density due to asymmetry of overlying soft-tissue may be incorrectly interpreted as lung disease.

Note the generalized increased density to the right hemithorax and well-defined homogenous density laterally with a well-defined margin representing a supine distribution fluid meniscus. There is midline shift to the left due to mass effect in the right hemithorax.
Mild cardiomegaly. \nModerate right sided pleural effusion. Right basal compressive atelectasis. \nLeft lung clear.

There is consolidation within the postero-inferior aspect of the right upper lobe immediately abutting the horizontal fissure and posterior aspect of the right oblique fissure. No internal cavitation. The remainder of the lungs are clear. 
No pleural effusions. 
Heart size is normal. 
Given the clinical details, this consolidation likely represents infective change.
Consolidation in the right mid/lower zone with effacement of the right heart border. \nThe right hemidiaphragm silhouette is clearly outlined. \nLeft lung clear.

With the patient centrally positioned, there are increased right lung field lucency, and no pulmonary markings peripheral to the medially displaced shadow of the lateral/peripheral margin of the hyperdense smaller (collapsed) right lung. Relatively wide ipsilateral/right intercostal spaces. Shifting of mediastinal shadows to the contralateral/left side. \nNo obvious or definite evidence of other lesions

With the patient centrally positioned, there are increased right lung field lucency, and no pulmonary markings peripheral to the medially displaced shadow of the lateral/peripheral margin of the hyperdense smaller (collapsed) right lung. Relatively wide ipsilateral/right intercostal spaces. Shifting of mediastinal shadows to the contralateral/left side. \nNo obvious or definite evidence of other lesions
Chest x-ray demonstrates very widespread randomly distributed innumerable tiny nodules in both lungs. There is no consolidation or pleural fluid and no mediastinal or hilar nodal enlargement.
Diffuse increased interstitial markings throughout both lungs, without a zonal distribution. \'Shaggy\' outline to the heart. \nTracheomegaly.
Bilateral pleural effusions are noted. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unremarkable in size and contour.
Multiple well defined nodules and masses without cavitation in both lungs are highly suggestive for metastases.
Thick walled left lobe cavitary lung lesions.
Chance finding of a cor dexter (i.e. dextrocardia). Notice that the aortic arch is on the left and there is intestine on the left, in contrast to the DDx situs inversus.
Multiple well defined nodules and masses without cavitation in both lungs are highly suggestive for metastases.
